title: Try 3 Drinks from Toni Tipton-Martin’s New Book, Inspired by Two Centuries of Black Cocktail History
author: Audrey Morgan

title: Jerk-Spiced Bloody Mary
author: Toni Tipton-Martin
story: Reprinted with permission from Juke Joints, Jazz Clubs & Juice by Toni Tipton-Martin, copyright © 2023. Photographs by Brittany Conerly. Published by Clarkson Potter, a division of Penguin Random House, LLC. The Bloody Mary has long been a popular morning-after drink, known for its ability to soothe symptoms of a hangover. There are just a few recipes in my collection of African American cookbooks for the classic combination, which is ordinarily made with vodka, tomato juice , Worcestershire sauce, and seasonings, but the drink is experiencing a bit of a renaissance lately. The Bottomless Bloody Mary on restaurant brunch menus, made more boldly with rum, flavored vodka, and potent spices, may be driving this trend. These Are Bartenders' Favorite Tomato Juices for Bloody Marys RELATED ARTICLE I love the flavor departure in the Bloody Maria , a fiery Mexican version built with tequila; or the complexity of iconic restaurateur-model-author-entrepreneur Barbara “B.” Smith’s Cajun Mary, which she included in B. Smith Cooks Southern-Style in 2009. Smith’s ode to Louisiana can be made sweet with Absolut Mango vodka or spicy with Absolut Pepper vodka and garnished with spicy baby okra and blue-cheese–stuffed olives. And my curiosity was definitely piqued by Pat and Gina Neely’s flavor-balancing act. The television food personalities re-imagined the morning libation with hot-pepper vodka, vegetable juice, barbecue sauce, and horseradish in their 2009 cookbook, Down Home with the Neelys: A Southern Family Cookbook . I also fell hard for the idea of Bloody Marys for a Crowd, in Elle Simone Scott’s 2022 cookbook, Boards —so hard that I included a version of the recipe in Cook’s Country magazine, where I am editor-in-chief. Elle starts by making a big batch of classic Bloodies, but for variety, she sets out a wide assortment of rim salts, skewers, and garnishes—everything from classic olives and celery to chicken wings and poached shrimp—so people can customize their drink to their heart’s content. Clarkson Potter / Brittany Conerly In the end, though, it was the Bloody Mary à la Jerk, included in Helen Willinsky’s 1990 book, Jerk Barbecue from Jamaica , that won me over. Inspired by its use of sweet-hot spices, the version that follows swaps rum for vodka and doubles easily to serve a large crowd. Rimming the outside edge of the serving glass with the jerk seasoning intensifies the island experience, but it is optional. Serves 8 to 10.
ingredients: [{'quantity': '1', 'unit': 'quart', 'ingredient': 'tomato juice'}, {'quantity': '1/2', 'unit': 'cup', 'ingredient': 'prepared jerk seasoning'}, {'quantity': '1', 'unit': 'teaspoon', 'ingredient': 'celery salt'}, {'quantity': '3/4', 'unit': 'ounce', 'ingredient': 'worcestershire sauce'}, {'quantity': '4', 'unit': 'ounces', 'ingredient': 'fresh lime or lemon juice'}, {'quantity': '1 1/2', 'unit': 'teaspoons', 'ingredient': 'hot pepper sauce, or to taste'}, {'quantity': '8', 'unit': 'ounces', 'ingredient': 'light or dark rum'}, {'quantity': '8–10', 'unit': 'lime or lemon', 'ingredient': 'lime or lemon'}, {'quantity': '8–10', 'unit': '', 'ingredient': 'celery stalks, with leaves'}]
steps: ['Combine the tomato juice, 1 tablespoon of the jerk seasoning, the celery salt, and Worcestershire sauce in a small microwave- safe pitcher. Microwave until bubbles just begin to form around the edge of the pitcher, 2 to 3 minutes.', 'Remove it from the microwave and stir to dissolve the seasoning. Add the lime juice, hot pepper sauce, and rum to the base.', 'Refrigerate several hours, until thoroughly chilled.', 'Place the remaining ½ cup jerk seasoning on a saucer. Moisten the edges of tall glasses with a lime wedge. Press the edge of each glass into the seasoning to create a spiced rim.', 'Add ice to each glass, then pour in the mix. Garnish each glass with 1 lime wedge and a celery stalk.']

title: Clover Leaf
author: Toni Tipton-Martin
story: Reprinted with permission from Juke Joints, Jazz Clubs & Juice by Toni Tipton-Martin, copyright © 2023. Photographs by Brittany Conerly. Published by Clarkson Potter, a division of Penguin Random House, LLC. The Clover Leaf is a floral, fruity, and sweet gin drink, made with grenadine (pomegranate syrup), lemon juice, and egg whites, resulting in a cocktail with the taste and mouthfeel of berry cream soda. It is sometimes confused with the Clover Club , which uses raspberry syrup in place of the grenadine and vermouth for the lemon juice. (Longtime Tulsa caterer Cleora Butler enjoyed combining grenadine and vermouth—pantry staples that are more accessible than raspberry syrup and fresh lemon juice.) Either way, the drink is sensational, and is another delicious way to serve that homemade grenadine mixed with Old Tom gin , which is mild and smooth. Clarkson Potter / Brittany Conerly If you prefer raspberry syrup to the grenadine, this updated option relies on Chambord, a luxury brand of black raspberry liqueur, to tone down some of the sugar. Pasteurized egg whites or half-and-half also replace the frothy raw egg. In either case, this technique demonstrates the high art of cocktail making, shaking to create a beautiful crown of foam.
ingredients: [{'quantity': '1/2', 'unit': 'ounce', 'ingredient': 'Chambord liqueur'}, {'quantity': '1/2', 'unit': 'ounce', 'ingredient': 'fresh lemon juice'}, {'quantity': '1', 'unit': 'ounce', 'ingredient': 'pasteurized egg whites'}, {'quantity': '1–1 1/2', 'unit': 'ounces', 'ingredient': 'gin'}, {'quantity': '1', 'unit': '', 'ingredient': 'mint leaf'}]
steps: ['Combine the Chambord or grenadine, lemon juice, egg white or half-and-half, and gin in a cocktail shaker with ice cubes.', 'Shake vigorously for 10 seconds, until the ingredients are cold and the mix is frothy with a pink blush.', 'Strain into a Martini or coupe cocktail glass, making sure there is a thin layer of foam and a few small ice chips floating on top.', 'Garnish with the mint leaf.']

title: Emerson
author: Dylan Garret
story: The Emerson is a classic cocktail consisting of gin, sweet vermouth, maraschino liqueur, and lime juice. It’s a close relative of the Martinez , itself considered a possible forebearer of the Martini. The exact origins of the drink are largely unknown, though some say the drink was named in honor of Ralph Waldo Emerson, and one of its earliest known appearances was in Jacques Straub’s 1913 book Straub’s Manual of Mixed Drinks . It mostly follows cocktails of the era, taking the spirit-plus-vermouth-plus-modifier template of drinks like the Manhattan and the Martini and adding its own slight tweaks. What Makes the Emerson Work Like the Martinez, the Emerson follows a structure of gin, sweet vermouth, and maraschino liqueur, but it differs in its modifier. While the Martinez uses bitters as its accent ingredient, the Emerson opts for a relatively small amount of lime juice. What this does is skews the cocktail away from the bitter and spirit-forward template of drinks and towards the sour category, though somewhat more subtly than other classic sours of the era like the Gin Sour or Daiquiri . What you get is a cocktail that straddles the line between these two worlds. 10 Cocktails to Make with Maraschino Liqueur RELATED ARTICLE At 1/4 ounce, maraschino liqueur is used in a relatively small amount here. However, it provides a substantial amount of backbone when considered as a sweetener. The grams of sugar by volume in maraschino liqueur are roughly double that of most sweet vermouths, meaning it’s easier to tweak small amounts of liqueur used in the Emerson to fit your preferred flavor profile rather than alter the volume of vermouth. Maraschino helps bring out the fruit-forward notes of vermouth and contribute sweetness while not overpowering vermouth’s more subtle qualities. In all, the Emerson is an interesting representation of two popular pre-Prohibition styles of cocktail fused together, and a fantastic option for fans of either citrus-forward sours or spirit-forward Martinez-style cocktails looking for something different.
ingredients: [{'quantity': '1 1/2', 'unit': 'ounces', 'ingredient': 'gin, preferably Old Tom'}, {'quantity': '1', 'unit': 'ounce', 'ingredient': 'sweet vermouth'}, {'quantity': '1/2', 'unit': 'ounce', 'ingredient': 'lime juice, freshly squeezed'}, {'quantity': '1/4', 'unit': 'ounce', 'ingredient': 'maraschino liqueur'}, {'quantity': '', 'unit': '', 'ingredient': 'maraschino cherry', 'note': 'Garnish'}]
steps: ['Combine all ingredients except garnish in a cocktail shaker filled with ice.', 'Shake for 10–15 seconds, until well chilled.', 'Double strain through a fine mesh strainer into a chilled cocktail glass.', 'Garnish with a maraschino cherry.']

title: Kansas City Ice Water
author: Audrey Morgan
story: The Kansas City Ice Water, also known as the KC Ice Water, is a simple cocktail that usually includes gin, vodka, lime juice, triple sec, and lemon-lime soda. The drink remains popular in its original form, but that hasn’t stopped some bartenders from seeking to improve upon its base template. This zesty, floral, and crowd-pleasing riff comes from Andrew Olsen, national beverage director of J. Rieger & Co , a historic distillery in Kansas City, Missouri. “The KC Ice Water was a common order in the high-volume bar scene of many college towns and local haunts, especially in the Midwest region,” says Olsen. “In 2017, when opening up a restaurant in the Country Club Plaza district, I recognized that popularity and wanted to make something that was reminiscent of the original flavors, but with a more craft element added to it.” “Our version stays with the vodka base but instead of splitting with gin, we use riesling wine,” he says. “This gives us great minerality and some brilliant fruit flavors like pear and green apple. Then we use a chamomile syrup that is somewhat parallel to the floral/botanical experience you get from the gin.” For the base, Olsen uses J. Rieger’s Premium Wheat Vodka , which is 100% wheat-based and has a rich texture due to a final distillation in a copper pot still . If you can’t source J. Rieger, look for another wheat-based vodka. Olsen also suggests using a kabinett riesling, which is a semi-dry, high-acid style. This recipe calls for a homemade chamomile syrup, which comes together easily on the stovetop and can be saved for use in other cocktails or for cooking and baking. You can source dried chamomile flowers on Amazon or at many grocery stores like Whole Foods. The cocktail is balanced with fresh lime juice and a coarse sparkling mineral water like Topo Chico or Jarritos Mineragua.

steps: ['Combine all ingredients except sparkling mineral water in a cocktail shaker filled with ice.', 'Shake for 15–20 seconds, until well chilled.', 'Pour sparkling mineral water in a highball glass, and strain the mixture from the shaker over it. Add fresh ice.', 'Garnish with a lime wheel.']

title: Champs-Élysées
author: Dylan Garret
story: The Champs-Élysées is a classic cocktail that consists of cognac, Green Chartreuse, lemon juice, simple syrup, and bitters. Named after the famous Paris avenue, it’s essentially a riff on the Sidecar that calls for Chartreuse rather than orange liqueur. The cocktail was first popularized in Europe, as the United States was still in the midst of Prohibition. The drink began to appear in cocktail books around 1925, when it was featured in Drinks—Long and Short by Nina Toye & A. H. Adair. In 1930, its profile grew further when it was included in Harry Craddock’s The Savoy Cocktail Book , which dialed up the recipe to punch proportions, meant to serve six. Despite these early 20th-century appearances, little is known about who first formulated the Champs-Élysées cocktail. Whatever the drink’s origins, it worked to bring attention to the mixability of French herbal liqueurs. It also contributed to the development of the sour category of drinks through bartender experimentation of previous iterations like the Sidecar and its forebearer, the Brandy Crusta . How to Make a Sidecar RELATED ARTICLE What Makes the Champs-Élysées Work While the Sidecar uses orange liqueur as its sweetener, the Champs-Élysées employs Green Chartreuse, an aromatic French herbal liqueur. When it’s combined with Angostura bitters, what you get is a deeper, more earthy and woodsy cocktail in the sour profile, as opposed to the Sidecar’s juicier, fruit-forward notes. This makes the Champs-Élysées a fantastic alternative for those seeking a sour style of cocktail while minimizing the potential for it to turn into a juice bomb. Lemon juice provides the needed acidity to balance the sweet elements, but the aromatics of the other ingredients create something that may be appealing to those who usually favor more spirit-forward cocktails. The drink is sweetened with both Chartreuse and neutral simple syrup, as the former ingredient would overpower the drink. Though this recipe calls for Green Chartreuse, those who wish for a more subtle touch may opt for the milder Yellow Chartreuse , which will come across as less perfumy in the final mix and has a slightly lower alcohol content. Green Chartreuse vs. Yellow Chartreuse: The Main Differences RELATED ARTICLE Worth noting, both styles of Chartreuse can be difficult to source at times, as production of the spirits is limited, and demand can often skyrocket. While there are no direct replacements for the classic liqueur, there are many newer alternatives that can work within the below specifications for a slightly different but delicious drink.

title: Bushwick
author: Dylan Garret
story: The Bushwick cocktail was created in 2009 by bartender Phil Ward at Mayahuel, the bar he operated in New York City’s East Village until 2017. Named after a neighborhood in Brooklyn, New York, this combination of rye whiskey, sweet vermouth, maraschino liqueur, and Amer Picon is essentially a riff on the classic Brooklyn cocktail that opts for sweet vermouth rather than dry. The Brooklyn, which debuted in the early 1900s, is  often attributed to a bartender who sought to create a new cocktail to stand alongside the iconic Manhattan and newly ascendent Bronx cocktail. Though it fell out of fashion through most of the 20th century—at least in comparison to the Manhattan—it saw a resurgence in the 2000s as bartenders continued to revive pre-Prohibition cocktails. While the original Brooklyn was created in an effort to capitalize on the trend of cocktails named after New York City boroughs, roughly 100 years later the Bushwick represented a new trend of bartenders naming cocktails after specific neighborhoods within those boroughs, like the Greenpoint , Red Hook , and Bay Ridge . Ironically, according to research by drinks historian David Wondrich in The Daily Beast , early Brooklyn recipes actually called for sweet vermouth, before later printings of the recipes in various cocktail menus began to make the switch to dry. Essentially, Ward’s Bushwick cocktail could be seen as a Brooklyn made to its original specifications. How to Make a Brooklyn RELATED ARTICLE What’s In a Bushwick? Ward’s original recipe called for a base of Rittenhouse Rye Whiskey, a 100-proof bottling that delivers a punchy 50% ABV. The drink also included Carpano Antica Formula, a notably rich sweet vermouth, and Luxardo maraschino liqueur . These ingredients make for a bolder style of cocktail, in which flavor-forward ingredients work to keep each other in check. However, when making one, feel free to play with various brands and expressions of rye and sweet vermouth to find the balance that works best for your tastes. The final ingredient is the trickiest for most to source—Amer Picon, a French aperitif flavored with bitter oranges and gentian. Unfortunately, the ingredient is famously unavailable to purchase in the United States, as one of its ingredients, calamus root, runs afoul of a mid-20th century Food and Drug Administration regulation still on the books. If you’re unable to source a bottle of Amer Picon, Ward has recommended swapping the ingredient with the more readily available Amaro Lucano . Other fans of the drink recommend Amaro CioCiaro as a suitable substitute as well.

steps: ['Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass filled with ice.', 'Stir for 15–20 seconds until well chilled.', 'Strain into a chilled coupe or Nick & Nora glass without garnish.']

title: Lychee Rosé
author: Prairie Rose
story: The Lychee Rosé is one of the few cocktails featured on Spago Beverly Hills’ Rare & Extravagant menu. It is also now Taylor Swift-approved . The mastermind behind the drink is bar director Adam George Fournier, formerly a Diageo World Class U.S. Bartender of the Year. Hired at the beginning of 2023 as the restaurant’s first dedicated bar director since the legendary Los Angeles restaurant opened in 1982, Fournier says that the Rare & Extravagant section on the revamped menu is a way for Spago “to highlight rare, unique, or luxury spirits.” The Lychee Rosé “was designed around Tequila Komos Reposado Rosa, a tequila aged in French oak ex-red wine barrels, [giving] it a unique flavor profile [and color],” says Fournier. “Essentially it’s our answer to a Lychee Martini.” We’re Drinking Like It’s 1999. Here’s How Cocktails Became Fun Again. RELATED ARTICLE The drink combines the rose-hued tequila with salted lychee cordial, manzanilla sherry, St-Germain elderflower liqueur , and fresh lime juice for a balance of perfumed fruit, tart citrus, and a touch of saline. At Spago, the cocktail is served in a glass shaped like a rose and garnished with a few delicate flower petals. At home, a chilled cocktail coupe will suffice. With or without the flower petal garnish this drink is sure to make the whole place shimmer.

title: Cadillac Margarita (El Cadí)
author: Audrey Morgan
story: There’s no one specific recipe for the Cadillac Margarita, and it might mean something different to whomever you ask. For Karla Flores-Mercado, proprietor of Bar Flores and other establishments in Los Angeles, it brings to mind Southern California’s old-school Mexican restaurants like Acapulco , where she bartended early in her career, serving Cadillac Margaritas with a shot of Grand Marnier for customers to pour over the drink. At Bar Flores, Flores-Mercado created the El Cadí in homage to restaurants that include Acapulco and El Compadre , home of the Flaming Margarita. In lieu of sour mix, Flores-Mercado’s version includes fresh lemon and lime juices for tartness, along with an earthy highlands tequila, agave syrup, and a Mexican orange liqueur. Finally, she tops the drink with a Grand Marnier float as a nod to the Acapulco Cadillac. “The Grand Marnier gives it a different vibe from just whipping up a sour,” says Flores-Mercado. “You get a little more booze but there’s also added sweetness, so it makes the Margarita a little easier to drink for some people.” For the tequila base, Flores-Mercado opts for El Tesoro Blanco , a benchmark highlands-style tequila with a rich mouthfeel and long spicy finish. “The earthiness really comes through in Margaritas,” she says. Since the bar program places an emphasis on sourcing Mexican spirits, Flores-Mercado uses Naranja Licor de Naranja , which she says is less sweet and more citrus-forward than other orange liqueurs. She also splits the sour component between lemon and lime juice, making for a slightly tarter drink that helps to balance the added sweetness from Grand Marnier. What Is a Cadillac Margarita? Again, there’s not one spec, but the Cadillac is generally a richer, more opulent version of the classic Margarita (blanco tequila and lime juice, sweetened with orange liqueur and/or agave syrup). A quick online search might yield recipes that call for lightly aged reposado tequila instead of the usual blanco, or the cognac-based orange liqueur Grand Marnier either swapped in for other triple secs or added to the drink as a float. Some Cadillacs are simply differentiated by the brand of tequila used, which is why you’ll often see somewhat meaningless terms like “premium” and “top shelf.” The origins of the Cadillac Margarita are murky, but it was popularized in the 1980s and ‘90s as chain restaurants began adding Cadillacs to their menus with substitutions like higher-end tequilas and the aforementioned Grand Marnier.

Set aside.', 'Combine all ingredients except the Grand Marnier in a shaker filled with ice. Shake vigorously for 25 seconds.', 'Double-strain through a fine-mesh sieve into the prepared glass over fresh ice.', 'Float Grand Marnier on top.']

title: These Make-Ahead Freezer Martinis Will Save Your Holiday
author: Audrey Morgan

title: Milady’s Martini
author: Audrey Morgan
story: This unique Martini recipe comes from our 2023 Liquor Legend Julie Reiner . With a career that spans nearly three decades, Reiner has shaped modern cocktail culture, past and present, at New York City bars that include Flatiron Lounge, Pegu Club, Clover Club, Leyenda, and most recently, Milady’s , a finalist for our Best New Bar of the year. “It’s always been a classic, but the Martini is having a moment right now,” says Reiner. “The Milady’s Martini is my take on the original and one of my favorites that we serve. We use gin, rosé vermouth, fino sherry, and Amaro Santoni, so it has a slight pink hue that we pair with a purple olive garnish. We serve it as a ‘cheeky’ size which is just a three-ounce pour [with sidecar], making this a great one to sip if you want to have multiple drinks without overindulging.” Julie Reiner Is Our 2023 Liquor Legend RELATED ARTICLE The drink is similar to Milady’s itself—a reimagined version of a classic. The original Milady’s, an old-school haunt in New York City’s Soho neighborhood, dated by some accounts to the 1940s but closed its doors in 2014. Reiner and partners Christine Williams and Susan Fedroff reopened the space in 2022, paying homage to its roots with a laid back ambience while introducing the well-crafted cocktails that Reiner has honed over her years in the industry. The Milady’s Martini is essentially a Martini made in the 50/50 style, with a split modifier of rosé vermouth and fino sherry. While some Martini recipes call for orange bitters, the Milady’s Martini includes a small amount of amaro. Reiner also opts for the freezer method of preparation, which is a great way to batch Martinis and other spirit-forward drinks for a crowd. Since this drink only features a few ingredients, it’s worth sourcing the intended bottles, although any London dry style of gin will work. Tio Pepe is a very dry fino-style sherry with notes of almonds and green apples, while Lustau’s rosé vermouth is made with a fino sherry base and shows a beautiful floral aroma. Amaro Santoni is bittersweet and complex, with prominent notes of Chinese rhubarb, sour orange, and baking spices. Feel free to serve a “cheeky” three-ounce version in a Nick & Nora glass, or simply sip it all at once.

steps: ['Combine all ingredients except garnishes in a small, 4–6 ounce sealable bottle or a small covered carafe. Place in the freezer for at least 2 hours prior to serving.', 'To serve, pour 3 ounces of ice-cold Martini into a chilled Nick & Nora glass. Garnish with a purple olive. Twist an orange peel and lemon peel over the drink before discarding peels.', 'Pour the remaining 1 ounce of Martini from the bottle over ice as a sidecar, or return to the freezer and use to top up the drink.']

title: Ramos Melon Fizz
author: Audrey Morgan
story: This fragrant take on the Ramos Gin Fizz comes from The Fox Bar in Nashville and includes toasted rice-washed gin and Midori. When writer Caroline Hatchett asked bartenders to share their favorite “uncool” spirits for a story , Fox Bar owner Laura Unterberg chose Midori, the melon-flavored, day-glo green liqueur most famously used in the Midori Sour . “We reach for Midori frequently as a modifier at The Fox Bar,” says Unterberg. “It’s easily one of the best-executed melon spirits on the market, and plays nicely with bright acidic sours, fern bar-era cocktails, and even adds a nice balance to the savory, leathery notes in mezcal and sotol.” Bartenders Share Their Favorite “Uncool” Spirits—and How to Use Them FEATURED IN This recipe is a riff on the Ramos Gin Fizz , a drink that relies on an infamously long shake time to emulsify all of the ingredients. “Midori adds a floral, summery backdrop to this lightly green take on the classic,” says Unterberg. This drink’s other main differentiator is toasted rice gin. The Fox Bar uses Wonderbird Gin No. 61 , which is made with fermented jasmine rice from the Mississippi Delta, then amps up the flavor profile by washing the spirit with toasted jasmine rice. To re-create at home, you’ll need a sous-vide machine or immersion circulator . You can skip this step, but what you’ll get is essentially a Ramos Gin Fizz with a splash of Midori (which will still be delicious). While a typical Ramos Gin Fizz calls for lemon and lime juices, The Fox Bar uses a lime stock recipe from Trash Collective , employing leftover lime husks gifted from a neighboring business, to reduce waste. Though optional for this recipe, citrus stock involves a simple 30-minute process of pressure-cooking spent citrus husks (pulp and all) in water, then straining and adjusting with acid and sugar to create a liquid that can act as a juice substitute or volume enhancer. “While you’re more than welcome to use fresh juice in this recipe, clarified lime will behave a little bit closer to stock,” says Unterberg. Finally, a dusting of imperial-grade matcha adds earthy notes that temper the cocktail’s sweetness, and plays nicely off the toasted rice gin.

steps: ['In a cocktail shaker, add all ingredients except the soda water. Dry-shake by shaking vigorously, without ice, for 15–20 seconds.', 'Add 1 square ice cube and 1/4 cup crushed or pebble ice . Shake until you can’t hear the ice in the cocktail anymore. Throw the drink once to aerate the cocktail by pouring it from one shaking tin into the other, drawing your hands apart as you do so to increase the distance of the pour.', 'Gently pour into a chilled Collins glass. Place in the freezer and keep undisturbed for 5 minutes.', 'Pull out of the freezer and carefully separate the edge of the foam from the rim of the glass with a metal pick.', 'Slowly add soda water down the center of the drink, making sure the foam is nice and thick and rises above the rim of the glass.', 'Insert a metal straw directly in the middle of the foam and dust with matcha.']

title: A Little Chili Punch
author: Dylan Garret
story: At Platypus, our Best Under-the-Radar Bar of 2023 , no ingredient goes unused. As the owners of a bar that launched during a period of pandemic-related uncertainty and snarled supply chains, Tony Saputo and Meredith Barry worked to ensure that liquor stocks were kept as tight as possible. They also introduced a perpetually rotating drinks menu that changed to reflect what ingredients they had on hand. This drink, A Little Chili Punch, is a tropical clarified milk punch that incorporates spices, pepper, and citrus to embody the bar’s ethos of innovation and scrappiness. “Not only does the drink look freakin’ awesome, but it really shines in what we do here,” says Saputo. “While we’re making original concoctions every week, and average about 250 new menu items a year, it’s hard to pick one type of drink that really showcases our skills and talents.” Liquor Awards: The Best of 2023 FEATURED IN A Little Chili Punch came about when the staff at Platypus was seeking a way to use a large quantity of jalapeño vodka in a large-batch cocktail, taking the base ingredient then adding layer after layer of complementary flavors to the final drink. “We organize events with multiple suppliers and sometimes this paints us into a corner that makes us think a little outside the box,” says Saputo. “This was one of those cases where we used Lifted Spirit’s Jalapeno and Herb Vodka to concoct a drink that not only played to the capsaicin qualities of jalapeño but showed the sweet and savory side of the pepper meat. This also let us lean into a tropical variety of flavors while using the astringency of the bourbon and tea to make a well balanced and delightful drink.” Saputo notes that making the drink is a long process, requiring around a week of total prep time to allow the flavors to fully integrate and the milk punch to clarify. However, the day-to-day upkeep is minimal, and mostly just involves adding a handful of ingredients each day, then being patient while waiting on the results. This recipe yields just under a gallon of punch, and will keep refrigerated for months. It’s a fantastic option for your next large gathering, or just to prepare ahead of time and have on hand throughout the season.

steps: ['1st Day Combine all citrus peels, pineapple, and sugar in a large container. Stir vigorously and let sit overnight in the refrigerator.', '2nd Day Add nutmeg, coriander, star anise, cardamom, allspice berries, and cloves to the mixture. Stir to combine. Let sit overnight in the refrigerator.', '3rd Day Add vodka, whiskey, amaro, and fernet to the container. For tea, steep four servings of passion fruit green tea in one quart of hot water for at least 30 minutes. Add hot tea, tea leaves included, to the container with the other ingredients, and immediately cover. Let sit overnight in the refrigerator.', '4th Day Add lemon juice to the cocktail mixture. In a separate large container, add the whole milk. Add\xa0 cocktail mixture to the container with the milk and stir to combine. Let the mixture sit, refrigerated, for 2 days. Agitate every 8 hours if possible, by stirring or shaking the sealed container.', '6th Day Strain your batched cocktail through a chinois strainer. The fat from the mixture will separate. Finish by straining again through a coffee filter until the cocktail is clear. When serving, pour 3 ounces of the cocktail into a rocks glass over a large ice cube, and stir for 30 seconds. Garnish with a carnation flower and sweet pepper, if desired.']

title: Dagwaagin (Fall) Squash Shrub
author: Dylan Garret
story: Owami by the Sioux Chef, the Minneapolis restaurant founded by Lakota Sioux chef Sean Sherman in 2021, aims to create a decolonized food and beverage program. This means eschewing ingredients introduced to North America by European settlers, including cane sugar, wheat flour, and dairy. While the restaurant offers beer and wine options that focus on BIPOC producers, its cocktail list is completely non-alcoholic. So, what does it mean to create a bar program that doesn’t utilize spirits, citrus, sugar, or any of the ingredients commonly associated with mixed drinks? “I like to make sure that each drink is not just something that is delicious to consume but that it’s providing something for the body as well,” says Jasmine Teague, bartender at Owamni. Liquor Awards: The Best of 2023 FEATURED IN Dagwaagin is a non-alcoholic fall squash shrub that’s become one of the restaurant’s most popular offerings. Apple cider vinegar  provides acidity and backbone in place of a more traditional alcoholic spirit, while maple syrup provides sweetness and ginger brings added heat and a spicy depth. The drink is served with a splash of soda water and mint to create an aromatic but easy-sipping spritz that utilizes all natively produced ingredients. Fall squash can include a wide range of vegetables. Common varieties include spaghetti squash, butternut squash, and pumpkin, which tend to offer sweeter, more mild flavors. Earthier squash like acorn, delicata, or kabocha can be substituted as well, though these may require more maple or mint to balance the drink to taste. Squash can be peeled and shredded with a food processor, or prepared manually with a box grater. Thinner-skinned squash like delicata can be processed with the skin on. This recipe creates a large-batch fall shrub that yields about 2 gallons. You can scale the recipe down for smaller batches by reducing the ingredients evenly. Either way, your shrub will keep sealed and refrigerated for about 6 months unopened, and around 8 weeks with use.
ingredients: [{'quantity': '4–5', 'unit': 'whole', 'ingredient': 'fall squash'}, {'quantity': '2–4', 'unit': '2–4', 'ingredient': 'fresh ginger'}, {'quantity': '3', 'unit': 'quarts', 'ingredient': 'maple syrup'}, {'quantity': '2', 'unit': 'cups', 'ingredient': 'water'}, {'quantity': '2', 'unit': 'tablespoons', 'ingredient': 'juniper'}, {'quantity': '4', 'unit': 'sprigs', 'ingredient': 'mint'}, {'quantity': '5', 'unit': 'cups', 'ingredient': 'apple cider vinegar'}, {'quantity': '', 'unit': '', 'ingredient': 'Soda water'}, {'quantity': '', 'unit': 'Garnish:', 'ingredient': 'mint sprig'}]
steps: ['Clean the squash. Wipe off any dirt and rinse under cold water. Cut off the squash stems, then peel or remove thick skin with a kitchen knife. Scoop out the seeds and strings (seeds can be saved and planted or gifted to friends for their own gardens).', 'Shred squash with a food processor or box grater. Repeat the process with the raw ginger.', 'Place squash, ginger, maple syrup, water, and juniper or peppercorn into a large pot. The squash should be nearly covered with liquid, just below the “squash line.” Mix the ingredients with a cooking spoon.', 'Bring mixture to a boil then lower to a simmer for 20–30 minutes, until squash breaks down. Drier squash may require additional water throughout the cooking process, so pour in water as needed to maintain the squash line, until the ingredients are cooked through and no longer fibrous.', 'Cook mixture down until a loose syrup forms and it reduces to roughly one third its starting volume. Taste and adjust as you go, but do not over simmer to a candy-like stage.', 'Remove pot from heat. Add mint sprigs to a separate heat proof container. Using a fine mesh strainer or cheesecloth, strain hot syrup over the mint. Reserve or discard solids.', 'Let syrup and mint sit for a minimum of 20 minutes. For best results, move to the fridge after 1–2 hours or let steep overnight.', 'After steeping, strain mint from syrup; reserve for another use or discard. Add apple cider vinegar to syrup, then stir together.', 'Serve 2–3 ounces of shrub over ice. Top with soda water, adjusting to taste. Garnish with additional mint sprig.']

title: Terroir Old Fashioned
author: Dylan Garret
story: Terroir is the sense of place that regional ingredients impart to food or drink based on where they were grown. Though popularized in the wine industry, the concept has increasingly been used to describe aspects of any regionally specific agriculture-based product, from tequila to honey. This cocktail from Overstory in New York City, our Best Craft Cocktail Bar of 2023 , was created by bar director Harrison Ginsberg. “It’s an Old Fashioned-style cocktail that is represented through terroir,” he says. “Every single ingredient in the drink comes from a very specific place.” The Liquor Awards: Best of 2023 FEATURED IN The base is reposado tequila infused with toasted palo santo, an aromatic hardwood native to parts of Central and South America. Agave nectar is caramelized to increase its depth of profile, while vin jaune, an oxidative style of wine from Jura, France (where it translates to “yellow wine”) adds nutty notes akin to those of a dry sherry. Yellow Chartreuse lends its signature herbal characteristics. Though tequila is the base spirit, the cocktail has a deep whiskey-like quality from the caramelized agave syrup that Ginsburg says result in a “Mounds Bar-like flavor.” To tie the drink to the terroir of the bar’s home city, Tilden sea salt, harvested from nearby Fort Tilden in the borough of Queens, New York, is added alongside housemade honeycomb. “The honeycomb has the nooks and crannies and webbing that the agave piña has, and also that honey-caramel note to it,” says Ginsberg. Though certain elements of the drink, such as the palo santo and housemade honeycomb, are tough to replicate, Overstory offered this take on the cocktail for those who wish to recreate some of the terroir of its signature Old Fashioned riff at home.

title: La Botana
author: Dylan Garret
story: Created by bartender Enrique Sanchez, La Botana comes from ABV in San Francisco, Liquor.com’s Best Neighborhood Bar of 2023 . It’s essentially a beer cocktail that utilizes a range of ingredients such as mezcal, orange juice, lime, habanero bitters, and house pickling liquid to create a flavor profile that’s emblematic of the bar’s approach. “We chose [to showcase] this drink since we’re known for our mezcal selection,” says Ryan Fitzgerald, manager partner of ABV. “It reads funky and scares a lot of people, but once they order it, they love it.” The Liquor Awards: Best of 2023 FEATURED IN ABV was founded in 2014 by a trio of hospitality veterans—Fitzgerald, Todd Smith, and Erik Reichborn-Kjennerud—who sought to create a more accessible space after years spent in more formal, speakeasy-style cocktail bars. La Botana features a pair of ingredients made custom at ABV: the bar’s house habanero bitters and a house pickling liquid. “The pickling liquid comes from the pickles that we make for the burger,” says Fitzgerald. “But instead of tasting like pickles, it tastes more like a really fresh cucumber shrub. That reminds us of the ‘botanas’ that are often served at restaurants in Mexico—slices of orange, cucumber, and jicama with spicy Tajín and lime juice.” While you’ll need to take a trip to ABV to try the original, authentic version of this cocktail, you can swap in a few substitutes to create a homemade La Botana. Brands like Bittermens now offer habanero bitters as part of their selection, and jarred pickle brine can stand in for ABV’s housemade version if you’re not up for making a cucumber shrub from scratch. Deceptively simple but complex in flavor, La Botana embodies our top neighborhood bar of the year.

title: Stone Fruit Sour
author: Dylan Garret
story: This riff on the classic Whiskey Sour comes from Pacific Standard in Portland, Oregon, the Best New Bar of this year’s Liquor Awards. It’s an approachable cocktail that’s easy to make but still expresses a wealth of flavor. “I love a Whiskey Sour, and always have,” says Jeff Morgenthaler, bartender and co-owner of Pacific Standard. “We touched it up with a dollop of egg white and a touch of apricot liqueur because stone fruits go so well with bourbon, especially Evan Williams bonded.” The Liquor Awards: Best of 2023 FEATURED IN The drink calls for rich simple syrup, which ups the ratio of sugar to water to 2:1, allowing the sweetness to come through without thinning out the drink. Combined with egg white, the rich simple syrup creates a rounder mouthfeel while still allowing the overproof base liquor to shine. All in all, it’s an accessible version of a classic drink, and embodies the style that Pacific Standard has become known for since opening in 2022. “It’s a failure of a bar when everyone is sitting around smelling their drinks and taking pictures of them,” says Morgenthaler. “I don’t need people thinking about the drinks, I need them enjoying them.”

title: Lavender Mule
author: Dylan Garret
story: The Lavender Mule is one of the signature cocktails of La Factoría, in San Juan, Puerto Rico. It’s a seemingly simple drink that consists of vodka, lemon juice, ginger tea, and a lavender and dry spice syrup, but behind these four ingredients, an array of subtle touches and preparation tweaks make the drink more than a sum of its parts. An approachable, refreshing crowd pleaser that offers a complex profile with layers of flavor, the drink mirrors La Factoría itself—our top honoree in the Expertise In Hospitality category of our 2023 Liquor Awards. The Liquor Awards: Best of 2023 FEATURED IN La Factoría founder and partner Leslie Cofresi describes the bar’s approach to cocktails as classics “with a little twist, to give a surprise.” It’s on display here, where a simple spin on a Moscow Mule incorporates a housemade lavender syrup enriched with toasted spices, and freshly made ginger tea adds heat while complementing the drink’s aromatic profile. Cofresi says the Lavender Mule itself came about by accident. “I was making Moscow Mules and [another] signature cocktail that used the lavender and dry spice infusion,” he says. “When we started running low on ingredients, I started mixing the ginger and the lavender and people went crazy over it. The drink is so simple and refreshing [that] it just caught on.” It has since become one of the bar’s most popular creations, and Cofresi says La Factoría now sells thousands of Lavender Mules each month. The public reaction to the drink has spread to other bars, where it’s now common to see lavender-themed creations that aim to capture some of the magic of the original drink. Though the ginger tea and the lavender syrup take a bit of extra prep time, both are fairly simple to make and can be easily put together in a home kitchen. The extra ingredients can be saved for future cocktails and will keep for a few weeks.

title: Petronio
author: Dylan Garret
story: Alquímico, in Cartagena, Colombia, has become renowned for its bar program’s focus on local ingredients, including those grown on its own 27-acre farm in Filandia. It’s earned accolades from the international drinks community and local fans alike, and was recently voted winner of our Global Spotlight category in the 2023 Liquor Awards. The Petronio showcases Alquímico’s unique approach to cocktails and how owner Jean Trinh and his team are utilizing regional ingredients to create innovative flavor profiles. The drink, which was named after the popular music festival Petronio Álvarez, features a base of reposado tequila, which has barrel-aged notes of vanilla that are accentuated by the addition of vanilla liqueur. Freshly squeezed lemon juice and orange juice bring in familiar citrus elements of other tequila-based sours, but a few other ingredients make this drink one of a kind. The Liquor Awards: Best of 2023 FEATURED IN Puré de lulo, or lulo puree, comes from a fruit typical to the region. It’s not as widely incorporated into drinks elsewhere, as the fruit’s delicateness makes it difficult to transport abroad. Outwardly it may initially appear as an orange, or orange-hued persimmon, but the green pulp within provides tart flavor that may strike some as a tangy cross between citrus, kiwi, pineapple, or something that’s just uniquely lulo. The cocktail’s other addition, viche, is a traditional homebrewed spirit made from sugar cane, primarily crafted by Afro-Colombian women from the country’s Pacific coast. Though the spirit was outlawed through much of Colombia’s recent history, a 2019 ruling that offered protection for ancestral Indigenous beverages was later expanded to those of Afro-Colombian heritage, legalizing the drink and giving it a new place on menus like Alquímico’s. Though some of these ingredients may prove more difficult to source for those outside their country of origin, specialty online retailers may be able to help. Either way, take this recipe as inspiration to go to the source and get the wholly Colombian cocktail experience directly from Alquímico.

title: Night Tripper
author: Dylan Garret
story: This bourbon-based cocktail comes from our Best Restaurant Bar of 2023 , New Orleans’s Jewel of the South. There, head partner and bartender Chris Hannah pays tribute to the city’s history through the bar program’s drinks, which feature numerous innovative riffs of classic Crescent City cocktails. “The Night Tripper was named for one of our local heroes, Dr. John,” says Hannah. “Amazing New Orleans piano player. What it says about our team, and Jewel, is how we love our city and draw inspiration from our local culture.” The Liquor Awards: Best of 2023 FEATURED IN The Night Tripper leans into the traditional spirit, sweet, and bitter profile of many classic aromatic cocktails. Hannah uses a bottled-in-bond bourbon as the base and adds two amari, Averna and Ramazzotti, though you can use any dark amaro of your choice. Peychaud’s bitters, invented in New Orleans by apothecary Antoine Amédée Peychaud in the mid-1800s, help bring depth and spice to the drink without clashing with the unique bitter profile of the amaro. Notably, the herbal liqueur Strega acts as a sweetening element, adding an extra dose of mint, anise, and fennel to the mix. Combined, just four simple ingredients create a flavorful drink that’s more than the sum of its parts. Fans of other spirit-forward New Orleans cocktails like the Sazerac or Vieux Carré will find familiar comfort here, but the Night Tripper’s profile is complex enough to stand on its own in the canon of modern classics. It embodies the spirit that has made Jewel of the South a local institution since opening in 2019, and an ode to the city it calls home.

title: Boothby
author: Dylan Garret
story: The Boothby is a pre-Prohibition cocktail that features rye whiskey, sweet vermouth, two types of bitters, and Champagne. It’s essentially just a Manhattan with the addition of sparkling wine. The drink is thought to have been created around 1910 at the Palace Hotel in San Francisco, and takes the name of its creator, William “Cocktail” Boothby, a prominent Bay Area bartender of the era. Boothy himself was an interesting character, who fell into bartending after stints bouncing around various odd jobs. Before launching his bar career, Boothby is stated to have worked as a vaudeville minstrel, a real estate agent, medical salesperson, and tailor, among other hustles. After transitioning to bartending in the late 1800s, Boothby even organized a coalition of fellow bar workers to get himself nominated and elected to the California State Assembly in 1895, after which he began to refer to himself as The Honorable William T. Boothby. The Origins of the Boothby The Boothby cocktail itself isn’t anything particularly special but is notable for its place in San Francisco cocktail culture, and William Boothby’s impact on bartending. His 1891 book, Cocktail Boothby’s American Bar-Tender , was one of the first of its type published on the West Coast, and offered instructions on a number of classics, as well as Boothby originals. His book wasn’t too dissimilar from those circulating around the East Coast of the U.S. at the time. In fact, Boothby hadn’t been tending bar for all that long before releasing his manual, which the cover states to be “endorsed by all clubmen and mixologists” and “sold by all newsdealers throughout the English speaking world.” It’s written in a rather casual manner, and includes standard recipes in addition to  sections that seem geared specifically for the trade. 15 Cocktails to Make If You Love Manhattans RELATED ARTICLE One section titled “Valuable Secrets for Liquor Dealers” gives some rather dubious tips, such as advising readers to fake longer-aged whiskey by adding prune juice to the barrel, or to approximate bourbon by adding various oils, ether, and wine vinegar to a proof spirit before coloring it with burnt sugar. A few pages later, a recipe for “Cheap Beer” instructs DIY brewers to use a combination of green pea shells and wood sage in place of hops. Other tips are much more functional, like “Do not serve a frosted glass to a gentleman who wears a moustache, as the sugar adheres to that appendage and causes great inconvenience.” Whatever your opinion of some of  Boothby’s more specific methods, he was a bartender’s bartender, whose advice seems to be particularly positioned towards industry brethren. He credited those who created recipes which were not his own, and his original cocktails, the namesake Boothby included, are mainly  classics with minor alterations. And, if you think about it, his techniques of fortifying spirits with prune juice, aromatic oils and vinegar aren’t too far removed from the “house infusions” of today’s bartenders. (If it helps with his street cred, he was also arrested in 1922 for violating the Volstead Act and serving alcohol during Prohibition.) The Boothby cocktail itself faithfully follows the classic Manhattan recipe, with the simple addition of one ounce of brut Champagne at the end. The sparkling wine adds a touch of effervescence to a familiar flavor profile, slightly lightening the drink, while the bubbles help to keep the palate fresh and unfatigued.

title: Manhattan Transfer
author: Dylan Garret
story: The Manhattan Transfer is a modern classic cocktail composed of rye whiskey, dry vermouth, Ramazzotti amaro, and orange bitters. It was created by pioneering bartender Phil Ward at New York City’s Death & Co in 2008, making it one of the early cocktails to be featured at the famed bar. It later appeared in the bar’s influential cocktail book Death & Co: Modern Classic Cocktails (Ten Speed Press, 2014). The drink could be seen as a variation on a Dry Manhattan, though the combination of whiskey, dry vermouth, and bitter amaro could also be viewed as a modified version of the Old Pal . The Old Pal, which follows a similar template but opts for its bitter amaro in the form of Campari, is just a modified version of a Boulevardier , which itself is simply a whiskey Negroni . This is all to say… cocktail names are funny. But the Manhattan Transfer falls squarely in the middle of a range of classic drinks and shows how easily you can play Six Degrees of Cocktails to quickly get from a classic Manhattan to a Negroni. 15 Cocktails to Make If You Love Manhattans RELATED ARTICLE Why the Manhattan Transfer Works The primary sugar in a Manhattan Transfer comes from Ramazzotti, a dark Italian amaro that delivers notes of licorice and citrus and a strong herbal profile to the drink. The added bitterness that comes from the amaro balances the sugar in the drink, which is technically higher than the total amount of sugar in a standard Manhattan . However, stronger aromatics create a distinctly bittersweet profile, and the drink is a good example of why sugar content and a drink’s perceptible sweetness are not always completely aligned. In contrast to a drink like the Old Pal (or any Negroni variation) that uses an even sweeter red bitter liqueur, like Campari, the Manhattan Transfer will present as a relatively dry cocktail. This dryness is accentuated by the use of a 100 proof rye whiskey (Ward’s original recipe calls Rittenhouse 100, an overproof bar standard), though the volume of whiskey is dialed down by 25% from a standard Manhattan to compensate for the boozier profile. Effectively, the total ABV of the Manhattan Transfer comes in at around the same as a traditional Manhattan, but the drink will still appeal to those who like a more heavily aromatic drink with a spicier, herbal profile thanks to its playful use of ingredients. While the original Death & Co version of the Manhattan Transfer does not come with a garnish, we've included an orange twist here to help accentuate the citrus aromas of both the Ramazzotti and orange bitters. Feel free to omit if preferred.

title: Bay Ridge
author: Dylan Garret
story: The Bay Ridge is a combination of rye whiskey, dry vermouth, Benedictine, prune brandy, and bitters. It can be considered a Manhattan derivative, both in composition and name. The drink originated around 2014 with Tom Macy , co-owner of iconic cocktail bar Clover Club in Brooklyn, New York, as part of a tongue-in-cheek revival of cocktails named after New York City neighborhoods. Since the early (and enduring) success of the Manhattan cocktail, other classics that took their names from New York boroughs, like the Brooklyn and the Bronx , began to pop up around the turn of the 20th century. Over a hundred years later, as modern bartenders began to revive forgotten classics, a new era of New York-themed cocktails began to spread to cocktail menus around the city, further subdivided into neighborhoods like the Greenpoint , Redhook , or, in this case, Bay Ridge. Most tend to be based around spirit-forward profiles, akin to the original Manhattan, though with certain twists. Why the Bay Ridge Works The Bay Ridge follows the whiskey-vermouth-bitters template of its predecessors, though with a few notable tweaks. While the Manhattan uses sweet vermouth to provide all the cocktail’s sugar, the Bay Ridge opts for dry vermouth, supported by Benedictine, an herbal liqueur, and prune brandy. 15 Cocktails to Make If You Love Manhattans RELATED ARTICLE The prune brandy is likely the hardest ingredient to source here, though also the one that most sets the Bay Ridge apart from similar cocktails. Macy opts for Louis Roque La Vieille Prune Plum Brandy in his recipe—distilled from three varieties of plums from the Armagnac region in the southwest of France, it’s then aged for 4–5 years in oak casks. This provides the cocktail backbone of plum, raisin, and baking spices that can be hard to replicate with other ingredients. If you’re unable to find prune brandy, an option may be to substitute a more accessible peach brandy to retain some of the intended stone fruit profile. Conversely, if you’re feeling open to experimentation and slightly lower proof, sherry can also help to recreate some of the brandy’s prune-forward profile—if you’re attempting this route, aim for a dry amontillado sherry which can help to create some of the brandy’s oxidative notes, without upsetting the cocktail’s sugar balance. However, if you’re aiming to recreate Macy’s recipe at home, sourcing prune brandy is the only way to go. Otherwise, you’ll just have to make the trip out to Clover Club to try the original for yourself.

steps: ['Combine all ingredients except garnish in a mixing glass filled with ice.', 'Stir for 15–20 seconds until well chilled.', 'Strain into chilled coupe or Nick & Nora glass, and garnish with an orange twist.']

title: Horsefeather
author: Dylan Garret
story: The Horsefeather is a combination of rye whiskey, ginger beer, bitters, and lemon. The de facto cocktail of Kansas City, Missouri, the drink is thought to have either originated there or in nearby Lawrence, Kansas (though exact origins are murky). As a member of the Buck family of drinks, or those that include ginger beer or ginger ale mixed with citrus and a spirit, the Horsefeather’s most popular relative would be the Moscow Mule . However, going by the name, the drink is more likely a derivative of the Horse’s Neck , which typically uses a bourbon base and ginger ale rather than the Horsefeather’s more strongly flavored ginger beer. It also shares relation to the Kentucky Buck , though that variation opts for lime over lemon, but at this point we’re basically just splitting, well, feathers. Why the Horsefeather Works Though ginger beer can come in a variety of profiles, quality options are often known for their spiciness and the heat that fresh ginger brings. A squeeze of citrus is a common pairing, as the acid from the fruit helps to cut the spice. How to Make Ginger Beer at Home RELATED ARTICLE The Horsefeather can be made with any type of whiskey. Rye whiskey’s relatively spicier and drier profile allows it to play off the heat of the ginger beer while integrating and absorbing its sugar. Bourbon will create a slightly sweeter tasting profile. For arguably the most authentic option, J. Rieger’s Kansas City Whiskey is a mainstay that combines both straight rye and straight bourbon whiskey, along with a small amount of oloroso sherry. The addition of sherry is a throwback to a common 19th century U.S. distilling practice, when tax laws forced many producers to bottle whiskeys young, and additives like sherry were often used to round out harsh flavors. Though this practice was often used to cover up the flaws of rushed production, it’s finding a new life in quality modern spirits that seek to recreate some of the unique elements of classic American whiskeys. The notable tweak that separates a Horsefeather from some of its common Buck-family siblings is the addition of Angostura bitters. This adds depth and a bit of tannic backbone to the drink, effectively making it a Mule for those who prefer a drier style of whiskey and ginger drink.
ingredients: [{'quantity': '1 1/2', 'unit': 'ounces', 'ingredient': 'whiskey'}, {'quantity': '4', 'unit': 'ounces', 'ingredient': 'ginger beer'}, {'quantity': '4', 'unit': 'dashes', 'ingredient': 'Angostura bitters'}, {'quantity': '1', 'unit': 'wedge', 'ingredient': 'lemon'}]
steps: ['Add whiskey, ginger beer, and bitters to a Collins or highball glass filled with ice.', 'Squeeze lemon wedge over the drink, and add the wedge husk to the glass.', 'Stir gently to combine.']

title: Fanciulli
author: Dylan Garret
story: The Fanciulli is a combination of whiskey, sweet vermouth, and Fernet-Branca. The cocktail is thought to date to around 1910, and is essentially a riff on the Manhattan , a popular cocktail of the era (or any era, really). While the cocktail’s name translates to an Italian slang word for “boys,” the drink is believed to be named after Francesco Fanciulli, a director for the United States Marine Band from 1892 to 1897, who succeeded John Philip Sousa. According to drinks historian Philip Greene , the trademark and internet counsel for the United States Marine Corps and founder of the Museum of the American Cocktail, Fanciulli refused a request by a superior to play a Sousa march during an 1897 parade. Fanciulli was placed under house arrest for “failure to obey a lawful order, use of disrespectful language toward an officer, and conduct being prejudiced to the conduct of good order and discipline.” 15 Cocktails to Make If You Love Manhattans RELATED ARTICLE Fanciulli eventually had his sentence mitigated by President Theodore Roosevelt, though his time with the Marine Band had reached an end. However, his legacy now lives on through both his music and the cocktail that bears his name. Why the Fanciulli Works As a fairly straightforward Manhattan variation, the Fanciulli adheres to the classic spirit-sweet-bitter ingredient combination. The primary difference between the Fanciulli and a Manhattan is its bitter component—rather than using the Manhattan’s bitters, the drink instead uses a quarter-ounce of Fernet-Branca, a menthol-forward Italian amaro . This creates a stronger aroma on the nose than your typical Manhattan, as well as a cooling effect when sipped. A seemingly small change, it completely alters the profile of the drink and makes the Fanciulli a rather unique cocktail. The 10 Best Cocktails to Make with Fernet-Branca RELATED ARTICLE The cocktail can be made with rye or bourbon. As with most spirit-forward cocktails, bourbon will generally present a sweeter-seeming profile, while rye brings spicier and more pepper-forward notes. Either style of whiskey can be used based on preference. However, there’s a slightly smaller ratio of sweet vermouth here than in a traditional Manhattan since the drink  is bolstered instead with fernet, which contains less sugar by volume. As such, bourbon’s sweetness can help to create balance and bring roundness to the cocktail, smoothing out the minty amaro’s more abrasive edges. Rye whiskey, on the other hand, will generally create a drier-tasting drink. Over a hundred years since it was first created, the Fanciulli remains a particularly well-balanced drink, and a fantastic way to mix Fernet-Branca into a cocktail .
ingredients: [{'quantity': '2', 'unit': 'ounces', 'ingredient': 'bourbon or rye whiskey'}, {'quantity': '3/4', 'unit': 'ounce', 'ingredient': 'sweet vermouth'}, {'quantity': '1/4', 'unit': 'ounce', 'ingredient': 'Fernet-Branca'}]
steps: ['Add all ingredients to a mixing glass filled with ice.', 'Stir smoothly for 15–20 seconds, until well chilled.', 'Strain into a chilled coupe glass.']

title: Scotch Sour
author: Dylan Garret
story: The Scotch Sour is a classic cocktail made with a combination of Scotch whisky, lemon juice, sugar, egg white, and sometimes bitters. It’s simply a spirit-specific version of the Whiskey Sour , a cocktail that can be made with any type of whiskey, but modern iterations at bars in the United States tend to employ bourbon unless specified otherwise. Though the change seems minor, the vast difference in flavor profiles between scotch and other forms of whisk(e)y creates an entirely different cocktail. History of the Scotch Sour The Sour category of cocktails is one of the oldest around, and typically involves a base spirit mixed with some form of tart citrus (usually lemon or lime juice) and a sweetening agent (like sugar, syrup, or liqueur) to create balance. The term itself can be preceded by any spirit type, and drinks like the Gin Sour and Brandy Sour have been enjoyed for over a century, though their popularity has generally been eclipsed by that of the Whiskey Sour. While domestically produced whiskeys created with corn, rye, and wheat dominated the U.S. market prior to the 1900s, Prohibition’s ban on alcohol created an additional demand for Scotch whisky. Though it was smuggled into the country illicitly during this period (generally through the Bahamas, which was a British colony at the time), scotch’s foothold in America lasted far beyond Prohibition’s repeal, and only grew as exports of the spirit increased after World War II. The Complete Guide to Scotch Whisky RELATED ARTICLE An outsized number of Whiskey Sours mixed in the latter half of the 20th century may have been made with scotch, but a glut in the whisky’s production (alongside a large number of scotch imitations) met a degradation of the cocktail itself, when pre-made “sour mix” increasingly took the place of fresh ingredients. What was once one of the oldest styles of cocktail often became a slug of scotch-flavored spirit combined with a three-second push of the “sour” button on a soda gun. As the millennium turned, U.S. whiskey production exploded, as did the resurgence of classic-style cocktails using their original ingredients. The Whiskey Sour became respectable again, and though it was increasingly made with bourbon, the Scotch Sour never truly went away. In fact, the drink became the basis of a new wave of modern classics, namely the Penicillin , a culture-changing cocktail from New York City’s Milk & Honey . This drink uses the Scotch Sour template but includes honey rather than simple syrup, and utilizes an additional float of heavily peated single malt scotch to highlight the full array of the spirit’s flavors. Why the Scotch Sour Works The combination of spirit, citrus, and sugar is so ingrained in cocktails because of how well the combination works across a wide range of ingredients. But what you get from the Scotch Sour is a predominantly malt-forward flavor that helps to create an earthiness not often found in sweeter, bourbon-based versions of the drink. The 10 Iconic Sour Cocktails Everyone Should Know RELATED ARTICLE Blended scotch tends to be the ideal whisky for a Scotch Sour, though a single malt can work as well. However, if the goal is to increase the peat and smoke elements of the drink, a variation like the Penicillin may be more ideal, where a single malt float allows for more of those elements to come through on the nose with each sip instead of getting blunted into submission by shaking. Though a Scotch Sour can effectively be made using just the three primary components (whisky, lemon juice, sugar), many Sours include egg white to create a creamier texture and rounder mouthfeel. This is optional and can be skipped for a cleaner tasting drink. We do, however, include two dashes of Angostura bitters here, which help accentuate some of the deeper and more tannic elements of blended scotch that can be lost in mixing the drink, bringing them back to the forefront. If using a more heavily peated whisky, the bitters can safely be omitted.

title: Frozen Piña Colada
author: Dylan Garret
story: The Frozen Piña Colada, a combination of rum, pineapple , lime, and coconut, is one of the most iconic drinks in the tropical cocktail canon. But despite its omnipresence in beach bars, pop culture, and 1970s songs about attempted infidelity, it can be hard to find one definitive recipe. As the national drink of Puerto Rico, the cocktail’s ties to the island are indisputable, but from there, the origins and recipe specifications get a bit murky. At least two of the Piña Colada’s origin stories go to the Caribe Hilton Hotel in San Juan, where two bartenders, Ramón “Monchito” Marrero and Ricardo García, each laid claim to having first created the cocktail in the 1950s. Another San Juan bartender, Ramón Portas Mignot of Barrachina, asserted he created the cocktail in 1963, and a plaque outside the establishment still touts it as the birthplace of the Piña Colada. Conversely, other stories date the combination of ingredients to the 1800s. The debate as to the true origins of the drink rages on today, and likely won’t be resolved any time soon. History's 10 Best Pineapple Cocktails FEATURED IN What this trip through ambiguous cocktail history really means is that, despite being a classic cocktail with a 70+ year history, the Piña Colada doesn’t have a definitive “traditional” recipe. For years, particularly during the craft cocktail boom of the early 2000s, many bartenders took to skipping the blender and preparing their Piña Coladas shaken and served on the rocks or over pebble ice , mirroring industry-wide trends that aimed to “class up” drinks that got a bad rap in the 1980s and ’90s. However, the one thing the two dueling originators of the modern drink, Caribe Hilton and Barrachina, agree upon is that the Piña Colada should be blended and frozen. Why The Frozen Piña Colada Still Works The Frozen Piña Colada mostly adheres to the classic sour template of spirit, sugar, and citrus in the form of lime juice. However, unlike many other classic examples of sours that use liqueurs or simple syrup to provide sweetness, the Piña Colada relies on the natural sugars found in pineapple, as well as those in cream of coconut. The result is a tropical drink that doesn’t taste sticky-sweet or like artificial sugar, but rather showcases the flavors of tropical fruit. Important to note is the need to use cream of coconut rather than coconut milk. Cream of coconut is a thicker and sweetened product that is needed to create the proper balance in a Frozen Piña Colada. Cream of coconut also has a higher fat content that creates a richer texture and mouthfeel, and provides structure to the cocktail to ensure it doesn’t dilute too quickly after blending.
ingredients: [{'quantity': '2', 'unit': 'ounces', 'ingredient': 'light rum'}, {'quantity': '1 1/2', 'unit': 'ounces', 'ingredient': 'cream of coconut, like Coco López'}, {'quantity': '1', 'unit': 'ounce', 'ingredient': 'pineapple juice'}, {'quantity': '1/2', 'unit': 'ounce', 'ingredient': 'lime juice, freshly squeezed'}, {'quantity': '1', 'unit': 'cup', 'ingredient': 'pineapple chunks, frozen'}, {'quantity': '1', 'unit': 'cup', 'ingredient': 'ice'}, {'quantity': '', 'unit': '', 'ingredient': 'pineapple wedge', 'note': 'Garnish'}, {'quantity': '', 'unit': '', 'ingredient': 'Maraschino cherry', 'note': 'Garnish'}, {'quantity': '', 'unit': '', 'ingredient': 'Pineapple leaf', 'note': 'Garnish'}]
steps: ['Ahead of time, place pineapple chunks, fresh or removed from the can, in a container in the freezer for at least an hour, or longer.', 'When ready to serve, combine all ingredients except garnish in a blender, making sure to shake the cream of coconut before adding. Puree until smooth, about 20–30 seconds.', 'Pour into a hurricane glass, and garnish with pineapple wedge, maraschino cherry, and pineapple leaf (and/or miniature umbrella).']

title: El Pepino
author: Dylan Garret
story: El Pepino, or “the cucumber” in Spanish, is another riff on the classic Margarita template, meaning it plays on some combination of tequila, lime juice, and a sweetener (typically triple sec or agave nectar). However, the Pepino is a cocktail that has taken on a life of its own, a riff upon which countless professionals and home bartenders have also riffed, each adding elements that aim to bring the drink beyond a simple muddled cucumber Margarita. In 2012, singer and actor Justin Timberlake launched the drink into the mainstream during an interview with Bon Appétit in which he namechecked the Pepino as his favorite cocktail. His version was said to be based on a creation of noted bar professional Junior Merino, which utilizes pineapple in addition to cucumber, tequila, and lime juice, with Grand Mariner as a sweetening agent. Another claim to the origin of the drink goes to Las Vegas-based Gaston Martinez, whose version omits pineapple but includes cilantro for an herbal kick, as well as egg white for texture in the style of a traditional sour. The Expansive World of Tequila, Mezcal, and Agave-Based Drinks FEATURED IN The truth of El Pepino’s origins is probably much more mundane, and it’s hard to definitively credit any single person with being the first to muddle cucumber slices into a Margarita. The recipe you’ll find here leans toward a more classic profile by omitting the pineapple juice to maintain acidic balance while letting the other ingredients shine. It also utilizes agave nectar rather than orange liqueur, in the style of a Tommy’s Margarita . Jalapeño adds an extra kick, and  works to both complement and balance the cucumber. Why the Pepino Cocktail Works When compared to more oddball combinations of esoteric cocktail ingredients, it’s not hard to see why the Pepino works well. The classic elements of a Margarita are all at play, balancing spirit, sweetness, and citrus. Using agave nectar, rather than the more processed and distilled sugar of triple sec , plays off the natural elements of tequila, an agave-based spirit. Additionally, the interplay between fresh lime juice and agave nectar works to accentuate the two primary elements of tequila’s profile—its citrus overtones as well as the spirit’s earthier aspects. This strikes an interesting contrast to a standard Margarita’s specifications, which simply dial up the citrus by adding orange liqueur on top of lime. Meanwhile, cucumber is muddled alongside jalapeño pepper, leveraging the classic combination of cooling and spice, rather than leaning on a single note of either. The amount of jalapeño can be dialed up or down based on heat preference, or even completely omitted if desired. Finally, the spicy-salty rim acts to reawaken the taste buds with each sip, so the Pepino remains engaging through to the final sip, rather than fatiguing halfway through the glass.
ingredients: [{'quantity': '2', 'unit': '1/4-inch wheels', 'ingredient': 'cucumber'}, {'quantity': '2', 'unit': '1/4-inch wheels', 'ingredient': 'fresh jalapeño'}, {'quantity': '1 1/2', 'unit': 'ounces', 'ingredient': 'blanco tequila'}, {'quantity': '3/4', 'unit': 'ounce', 'ingredient': 'agave syrup'}, {'quantity': '1', 'unit': 'ounce', 'ingredient': 'lime juice'}, {'quantity': '', 'unit': '', 'ingredient': 'Chili-salt rim', 'note': 'Garnish'}]

title: Mexican Martini
author: Prairie Rose
story: The Mexican Martini isn’t especially Mexican, or even a Martini. But for decades, it’s been the unofficial signature cocktail of Austin, Texas, where it has a deeply devoted following. Essentially a Margarita variation, the Mexican Martini was originally created at Austin’s Cedar Door over 40 years ago. As with many cocktail origin stories, the drink’s genesis is a little fuzzy. But according to local bar lore, a Cedar Door employee visited a small border town in Mexico in the early 1980s and was struck by how the Margaritas were served there: up, in an elegant Martini-style glass, rather than on the rocks or in a large Margarita glass. The bar adopted this idea and gave it the Mexican Martini moniker, taking the combination further with olive garnishes and eventually even adding a little olive brine to the mix itself. Margarita 1272 ratings On paper, this Margarita and Dirty Martini mashup may seem a little odd, but for the legion of fans who’ve put away Texas-sized amounts of Mexican Martinis over the years, the sweet and savory combo works just fine. The traditional Margarita ingredients of tequila, Cointreau, and fresh lime juice get a saline boost from a half-ounce of green-olive brine—directly from the jar, as they do it at the Cedar Door. Salt is well known to enhance the flavors of tequila, and the brine delivers on that while adding earthy, savory qualities to the drink. This recipe from Cedar Door offers the option to add a salted rim to the glass, but you may not need it with the brine and olive garnish additions.

title: Rosita
author: Dylan Garret
story: The Rosita is a modern classic cocktail most often described as a tequila Negroni , though this simplistic explanation vastly undersells the drink. Both involve a combination of spirit, Campari, and vermouth, though the Rosita splits the latter ingredient into equal parts sweet and dry vermouth, making it more akin to a Perfect Negroni. Further, it incorporates a dash of Angostura bitters, to bring added depth to the bittersweet combination. The Rosita’s history is murky, like that of so many classic and modern-classic drinks before it. Iterations of the cocktail date to at least the 1970s, before an early recipe was eventually featured in the Mr. Boston Official Bartender’s Guide . There, it sat buried in the book’s pages for years until eventually being unearth and riffed upon by bar legend Gary “Gaz” Regan . As Regan wrote for The San Francisco Chronicle , in the mid-2000s fellow drinks writer Terry Sullivan had discovered the drink, but upon further conversation between the two, neither could recall where the origins of Sullivan’s Rosita recipe lay. A bit of digging and the pair finally realized where Sullivan had found his information—in Regan’s own 1991 cocktail book, The Bartender’s Bible . “I didn't remember putting Rosita in The Bartender's Bible , but it's there all right,” wrote Regan. “Where did I steal that one from, I wondered.” The Expansive World of Tequila, Mezcal, and Agave-Based Drinks FEATURED IN The cocktail continues to work on every level. Regan’s version dials up the amount of tequila, deviating further from the equal-parts Negroni template. Splitting the vermouth to include both sweet and dry iterations creates a smoother tasting drink that avoids the sometimes-cloying profile many Negroni variants get from a full sugary ounce of both Campari and sweet vermouth. The final touch, a single dash of Angostura bitters, helps bring additional backbone to the Rosita, and helps to even out this rebalancing of vermouth. The result is a cocktail that perfectly fits the definition of a “modern classic.” It will appeal to those looking for a new spirit-forward tequila cocktail that avoids the trap of yet-another Margarita riff, or for Negroni fans seeking a variation that goes beyond a simple swap of the main spirit.

title: Tia Mia
author: Prairie Rose
story: The Mai Tai may be one of the most famous rum-based cocktails ever created. It has also been famously riffed on and tweaked over the years—and not always successfully. There are entire Reddit threads dedicated to the worst Mai Tai recipes found in the wild. That said, as far as adaptable cocktails go, the Mai Tai is easier than most to alter due to its fairly straightforward ingredient list and recipe. Bartender Ivy Mix, co-owner of Leyenda in Brooklyn, New York, merged her passion for mezcal with this classic drink when she created the smoky, complex Tia Mia—an anagram of Mai Tai. Mai Tai 595 ratings In 2010, influential bar maven Julie Reiner opened the Hawaiian-themed restaurant and bar, Lani Kai, in New York City, and the Tia Mia was Mix’s contribution to the drinks list—her first on a Reiner cocktail menu. Lani Kai closed after a two-year run, but when Reiner and Mix partnered on Leyenda, the Tia Mia went on the opening menu and has remained a staple ever since. The cocktail is also featured in Mix’s book, Spirits of Latin America . When Mix first started experimenting with this drink, she floated an ounce of mezcal atop a Mai Tai in place of the dark rum typically used. She eventually did away with the float altogether and swapped in a smoky mezcal and a funky Jamaican rum for the base. The orange curaçao, orgeat, and fresh lime juice hew to the traditional Mai Tai recipe, but the slightly modified proportions result in a drier, more complex drink.

title: Café Royal's Tequila Matador
author: Prairie Rose
story: This historic yet under-the-radar cocktail first appeared in the Café Royal Cocktail Book , which was published in 1937 by the United Kingdom Bartenders Guild (UKBG). Head bartender at the London-based Café Royal and President of the UKBG, William J. “Billy” Tarling curated this compilation of recipes, which features a range of cocktails that were being served in London’s fashionable bars and restaurants at the time. Interestingly, many of the drinks profiled in the book involve some of the earliest known recipes to use vodka and tequila in cocktails, both unusual spirits to mix with at the time. Tequila Martini 51 ratings The original Matador recipe is an equal-parts mixture combining tequila, dry vermouth, and orange curaçao. A Trader Vic’s riff also called the Tequila Matador first popped up in the 1972 edition of Trader Vic’s Bartender’s Guide, and transformed the drink into a tropical concoction that includes pineapple and lime juice. However, the original Café Royal formulation may be more suited to modern tastes that prefer drier, more spirit-forward cocktail profiles. This lesser-known recipe would be a fine replacement for a Martini, albeit a more aromatic and slightly less boozy order. The equal-parts ratio also frames itself well as an aperitif cocktail or pre-dinner sipper. While spirit-forward cocktails are typically stirred, the original recipe instructs the drink maker to shake the ingredients. In the spirit of staying true to the original creation, we’ve let that step remain. Perhaps you’d like an extra-cold drink with slightly more dilution—as with all cocktail interpretations, the final execution is up to you.

steps: ['Add the orange cuaçao, dry vermouth, and tequila into a shaker with ice.', 'Shake until well-chilled.', 'Strain into a chilled coupe or Nick & Nora glass.']

title: Mezcal Paloma
author: Audrey Morgan
story: The Paloma’s simple formula—tequila, lime juice, and grapefruit soda, built directly in the glass—lends itself to countless variations. One of the easiest is this smoky riff that swaps the classic blanco tequila for mezcal . Mezcal has been made in Mexico for centuries and is traditionally sipped neat, but the early 2000s saw bartenders in the U.S. experimenting with the spirit in cocktails like the Oaxaca Old Fashioned and Mezcal Negroni . As an agave-based spirit composed of a wider range of sub-categories including tequila, mezcal is a natural substitution in drinks like the Margarita or Paloma . Like tequila, it adds earthy and vegetal notes to a cocktail, but it’s generally more smoky and savory. What Is Mezcal? A Guide to Mexico’s Most Beloved Spirit RELATED ARTICLE Since there are only three ingredients in a Mezcal Paloma, using fresh lime juice and a high-quality mezcal will go a long way. Squirt and Jarritos are common grapefruit soda brands, and both are bartender favorites that are available stateside. Squirt will offer a slightly tarter flavor profile, while Jarritos may appeal to those seeking a sweeter drink.
